content.raw: Just checking, do we need a different visibility macro? Can't we use `IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE`?
content.html: Just checking, do we need a different visibility macro? Can't we use IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE?

content.raw: It must be different to work on windows (dllexport/dllimport) since this is in a separate library `ignition-transport3-log`.
content.html: It must be different to work on windows (dllexport/dllimport) since this is in a separate library ignition-transport3-log.

content.raw: I trust you but I still don't understand why we can't reuse the macro that we have. At the end of the day, the macro will be replaced with the appropriate `dllexport`/`dllimport`.
content.html: I trust you but I still don't understand why we can't reuse the macro that we have. At the end of the day, the macro will be replaced with the appropriate dllexport/dllimport.

content.raw: When `IGNITION_TRANSPORT_LOG_VISIBLE` is `dllexport` `IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE` is `dllimport`. The export macro must be replaced with `dllexport` while the library is being built, and `dllimport` when something is using the library. When `ignition-transport3-log` is building it is using the already built `ignition-transport3`, so `IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE` must be `dllimport`.
content.html: When IGNITION_TRANSPORT_LOG_VISIBLE is dllexport IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE is dllimport. The export macro must be replaced with dllexport while the library is being built, and dllimport when something is using the library. When ignition-transport3-log is building it is using the already built ignition-transport3, so IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE must be dllimport.

content.raw: `const OpenMode _mode`?
content.html: const OpenMode _mode?

Interestingly, the const on an lvalue parameter in a function declaration signature does not need to match the const on an lvalue in the function definition signature. In other words, the following is completely valid C++:

// in foo.hh
void foo(int a);

// in foo.cc
void foo(const int a)
{
  /* definition of foo */
}

Some experts recommend that you leave the const off of lvalue parameters in the function declaration because

  1. The user doesn't need to know that the parameter is const within the function definition
  2. It could easily be misinterpreted by the user as a const-reference
  3. It makes for a longer function declaration

I think the one disadvantage to leaving off the const is that it can be confusing for developers when the declaration and definition signatures don't immediately appear to match each other.

content.raw:
If there's no objections, I plan on replacing `time_recv_sec` and `time_recv_nano` with one column `time_recv` which is in nanoseconds since UTC. SQLite3 can store 8 byte signed integers, which means the nanoseconds time column should be fine for about 240 years from now.

Selecting all messages after a time goes from 

```SQL
SELECT * FROM messages WHERE (time_recv_sec > 1513379720 OR (time_recv_sec == 1513379720 AND time_recv_nano > 352233612)) ORDER BY time_recv_sec, time_recv_nano;
```

to

```SQL
SELECT * FROM messages WHERE time_recv > 1513379720352233612 ORDER BY time_recv;
```
content.html:
If there's no objections, I plan on replacing time_recv_sec and time_recv_nano with one column time_recv which is in nanoseconds since UTC. SQLite3 can store 8 byte signed integers, which means the nanoseconds time column should be fine for about 240 years from now.

Selecting all messages after a time goes from 

SELECT * FROM messages WHERE (time_recv_sec > 1513379720 OR (time_recv_sec == 1513379720 AND time_recv_nano > 352233612)) ORDER BY time_recv_sec, time_recv_nano;

to

SELECT * FROM messages WHERE time_recv > 1513379720352233612 ORDER BY time_recv;

content.raw:
I'm probably doing some arithmetic incorrectly, but I'm getting that an 8-byte signed integer representation of nanoseconds only lasts for a little under 30 years. If measured from UTC, it would cut off just before the year 1990.

Here's the expression I'm using to compute the maximum representable year. If I have an error, please let me know:

```
2^(8*8-1)/10e9/60/60/24/365 + 1960
```

A breakdown using words:

```
2^(num_bytes * bits_per_byte - sign_bit)/nanosecs_per_second/seconds_per_minute/minutes_per_hour/hours_per_day/days_per_year + first_year_of_UTC
```
content.html:

Here's the expression I'm using to compute the maximum representable year. If I have an error, please let me know:

2^(8*8-1)/10e9/60/60/24/365 + 1960

A breakdown using words:

2^(num_bytes * bits_per_byte - sign_bit)/nanosecs_per_second/seconds_per_minute/minutes_per_hour/hours_per_day/days_per_year + first_year_of_UTC

content.raw: nanoseconds_per_second = 1e9 instead of 10e9 (also utc epoch is 1970)
content.html: nanoseconds_per_second = 1e9 instead of 10e9 (also utc epoch is 1970)

content.html: Yep, that'll do it.

content.raw:
Playback of all topics from a logged file now works from the command line in  016b4cd , but it's awful code. It doesn't yet use the raw publishers in pull request #251 so it can't publish custom messages.

```
# publish some topics, modifying the ignition transport examples is a good way to get a publisher
ign log record -v 4 --file test.tlog
```

Then 

```
# Playback the recorded log
ign log playback -v 4 --file test.tlog
```

Stuff to do

* Log needs to check the schema version (see [how to do that here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/246/record-proof-of-concept-do-not-merge/diff#Ltools/record/src/playback.cppT88))
* Log needs an api to get topics (see [how to do that here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/246/record-proof-of-concept-do-not-merge/diff#Ltools/record/src/playback.cppT113))
* Playback needs to create all publishers at the start (see [how to do that here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/246/record-proof-of-concept-do-not-merge/diff#Ltools/record/src/playback.cppT178))
* `MsgIter` has a lot of todo's to make it implement `input iterator`
* Playback class needs tests
* Plus all the stuff in the pull request description

@mxgrey FYI
content.html:
Playback of all topics from a logged file now works from the command line in 016b4cd , but it's awful code. It doesn't yet use the raw publishers in pull request #251 so it can't publish custom messages.

# publish some topics, modifying the ignition transport examples is a good way to get a publisher
ign log record -v 4 --file test.tlog

Then 

# Playback the recorded log
ign log playback -v 4 --file test.tlog

Stuff to do

  • Log needs to check the schema version (see how to do that here)
  • Log needs an api to get topics (see how to do that here)
  • Playback needs to create all publishers at the start (see how to do that here)
  • MsgIter has a lot of todo's to make it implement input iterator
  • Playback class needs tests
  • Plus all the stuff in the pull request description

@mxgrey FYI

content.raw:
I think for right now `MsgIter() != iter` is a reasonable approach for determining when we've exceeded the final message, but in the long-term we should consider having a message container object (e.g. the `Batch` class in the design document) and have the `MsgIter` (or maybe a `Batch::iterator`) class tied to the container object. Then we can compare the iterator object to `container.end()` so that our iterator class is more consistent with the standard way that iterators get used in C++. That way, we'd even be compatible with range-for loops.

It may be the case that the "container" object would actually be something more like a `raii_sqlite3::Statement` factory rather than a traditional container object, but that wouldn't be an issue as long as the semantics match up.
content.html:
I think for right now MsgIter() != iter is a reasonable approach for determining when we've exceeded the final message, but in the long-term we should consider having a message container object (e.g. the Batch class in the design document) and have the MsgIter (or maybe a Batch::iterator) class tied to the container object. Then we can compare the iterator object to container.end() so that our iterator class is more consistent with the standard way that iterators get used in C++. That way, we'd even be compatible with range-for loops.

It may be the case that the "container" object would actually be something more like a raii_sqlite3::Statement factory rather than a traditional container object, but that wouldn't be an issue as long as the semantics match up.

content.raw: fd5959fffed0 makes `Log` return a `Batch` that supports range-based for loops and internally does the SQL statement construction. That commit doesn't change `MsgIter` to `Batch::iterator`, but I'm not opposed to doing so.
content.html: fd5959fffed0 makes Log return a Batch that supports range-based for loops and internally does the SQL statement construction. That commit doesn't change MsgIter to Batch::iterator, but I'm not opposed to doing so.

content.raw:
> How can record get notified of new topics? For example, record may be launched before the thing it is supposed to record starts recording. Record would only be subscribed to the ones it saw at launch.

As a stopgap measure, how would we feel about a special case where passing an empty topic string to `Node::Subscribe(~)` implies that the user wants to subscribe to all topics?

A cleaner long-term solution might be to add something like a filter field to `SubscribeOptions` such as a `std::function<bool(const Advertisement&)>` where `Advertisement` would be meta-data provided by the advertiser (e.g. topic name, time stamp, uuid of the advertising node, maybe other things?). Each time a new topic is advertised, we could run the filter of each qualified subscriber. "Qualified subscriber" refers to any subscribers who either (1) subscribed to the advertised topic name, or (2) left the topic name blank while subscribing. If the filter `std::function<bool(const Advertisement&)>` returns true, then we add the subscription; if it returns false, then we ignore the advertisement. By default, `SubscribeOptions` would not filter anything.
content.html:
How can record get notified of new topics? For example, record may be launched before the thing it is supposed to record starts recording. Record would only be subscribed to the ones it saw at launch.

As a stopgap measure, how would we feel about a special case where passing an empty topic string to Node::Subscribe(~) implies that the user wants to subscribe to all topics?

A cleaner long-term solution might be to add something like a filter field to SubscribeOptions such as a std::function<bool(const Advertisement&)> where Advertisement would be meta-data provided by the advertiser (e.g. topic name, time stamp, uuid of the advertising node, maybe other things?). Each time a new topic is advertised, we could run the filter of each qualified subscriber. "Qualified subscriber" refers to any subscribers who either (1) subscribed to the advertised topic name, or (2) left the topic name blank while subscribing. If the filter std::function<bool(const Advertisement&)> returns true, then we add the subscription; if it returns false, then we ignore the advertisement. By default, SubscribeOptions would not filter anything.

content.raw:
I'm trying to quickly implement the empty topic name proposal, but it seems like there may be some complications with respect to the partition and namespace of the fully qualified topic name.

The `HandlerStorage` class maintains a map of subscription handlers whose key is a fully qualified topic name. When a publisher advertises itself, it advertises its "topic" as a fully qualified topic name, and we compare that string against the map in `HandlerStorage`.

The trouble I'm having at the moment is it seems the `HandlerStorage` class would need some way to understand the fully qualified topic strings in order to recognize when an "empty" topic is provided to it, either by a node that's adding a subscription handler or by an incoming message from a remote publisher. It seems like we can reliably expect fully qualified topic names to follow a pattern of either `@/<partition_name>@/<namespace>/<topic>` or `@/<partition_name>@/<topic>`, but I'm under the impression that `<namespace>` and `<topic>` may contain arbitrary slashes within themselves, so it's not clear to me that we can always correctly identify the basic topic name from within a fully qualified topic name. The fully qualified topic name seems to lose information about where the namespace ends and the topic name begins.

As it currently stands, it doesn't seem possible for a node to latch onto arbitrary new publishers as they advertise themselves; at least not without some kind of small redesign of the `HandlerStorage` class.
content.html:
I'm trying to quickly implement the empty topic name proposal, but it seems like there may be some complications with respect to the partition and namespace of the fully qualified topic name.

The HandlerStorage class maintains a map of subscription handlers whose key is a fully qualified topic name. When a publisher advertises itself, it advertises its "topic" as a fully qualified topic name, and we compare that string against the map in HandlerStorage.

The trouble I'm having at the moment is it seems the HandlerStorage class would need some way to understand the fully qualified topic strings in order to recognize when an "empty" topic is provided to it, either by a node that's adding a subscription handler or by an incoming message from a remote publisher. It seems like we can reliably expect fully qualified topic names to follow a pattern of either @/<partition_name>@/<namespace>/<topic> or @/<partition_name>@/<topic>, but I'm under the impression that <namespace> and <topic> may contain arbitrary slashes within themselves, so it's not clear to me that we can always correctly identify the basic topic name from within a fully qualified topic name. The fully qualified topic name seems to lose information about where the namespace ends and the topic name begins.

As it currently stands, it doesn't seem possible for a node to latch onto arbitrary new publishers as they advertise themselves; at least not without some kind of small redesign of the HandlerStorage class.

content.raw: It should be noted that this issue has been resolved by simply using the `MsgDiscovery` class.
content.html: It should be noted that this issue has been resolved by simply using the MsgDiscovery class.

content.raw:
We can't use `ign_find_package` here until we get the [Components pull request merged](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/2). It's only the `log` component of the project that currently depends on `ign-common0`, so using `ign_find_package` would introduce a new required dependency to the core `ign-transport` package.

Bumping to `ign-common1` should be totally fine, though.
content.html:
We can't use ign_find_package here until we get the Components pull request merged. It's only the log component of the project that currently depends on ign-common0, so using ign_find_package would introduce a new required dependency to the core ign-transport package.

Bumping to ign-common1 should be totally fine, though.

content.raw: If it is alright with you I would like to not include them because they are used in the API define in `Batch.hh`. Adding them makes it possible for the build to succeed even if `Batch.hh` was missing those includes. Not including them means we catch that at compile time instead of a user catching it at their compile time.
content.html: If it is alright with you I would like to not include them because they are used in the API define in Batch.hh. Adding them makes it possible for the build to succeed even if Batch.hh was missing those includes. Not including them means we catch that at compile time instead of a user catching it at their compile time.

content.raw: I'm pretty sure `static` doesn't do anything here. If there are no objections I'll remove it. (same below)
content.html: I'm pretty sure static doesn't do anything here. If there are no objections I'll remove it. (same below)

Looks like I'm wrong here. Removing static leads to a compile time error when Recorder tries to use the constant it without an instance.

Also

#include <iostream>


class ConstCheck1
{
  public:
    const int member0 = 5;
    const int member1 = 5;
    const int member2 = 5;
    const int member3 = 5;
    const int member4 = 5;
    const int member5 = 5;
    const int member6 = 5;
    const int member7 = 5;
    const int member8 = 5;
    const int member9 = 5;
};


class StaticConstCheck1
{
  public:
    static const int member0 = 5;
    static const int member1 = 5;
    static const int member2 = 5;
    static const int member3 = 5;
    static const int member4 = 5;
    static const int member5 = 5;
    static const int member6 = 5;
    static const int member7 = 5;
    static const int member8 = 5;
    static const int member9 = 5;
};


int main(int argc, char ** argv)
{
  std::cout << "const only size: " << sizeof(ConstCheck1) << "\n";
  std::cout << "static const size: " << sizeof(StaticConstCheck1) << "\n";
  return 0;
}

non-static const does increase the size of the object, so the value is copied with each instance.

$ g++ --std=c++11 text.cpp 
$ ./a.out 
const only size: 40
static const size: 1

content.raw: Ahhhh, right, this is class definition scope, so the meaning of `static` is different. That must be the most irritatingly context-sensitive keyword in this entire language.
content.html: Ahhhh, right, this is class definition scope, so the meaning of static is different. That must be the most irritatingly context-sensitive keyword in this entire language.
